author: abnog
title: #24 Estudio encuentra que el castigo f√≠sico predice habilidades cognitivas m√°s bajas en ni√±os. (ENG)
text:
[NoEresTuSoyYo](/user/NoEresTuSoyYo)a [psypost.org](/go/link/3891531)
Esto se sabe hace d√©cadas. La gente no grita o pega a sus hijos porque crea realmente que eso les ayude, sino porque sienten el impulso de hacerlo, y las consecuencias a medio o largo plazo les importan una mierda. (Y tambi√©n c√≥mo se puedan sentir sus hijos, obviamente.)
[#2](c2#c-2) o los castigos de "a tu habitaci√≥n" o "al rinc√≥n". Es simplemente porque no puedes lidiar con la situaci√≥n y te liberas de es situaci√≥n que no puedes controlar.
[#7](c7#c-7) Puedes ejercer la autoridad y poner l√≠mites a tus hijos sin necesidad de faltarles al respeto ni usar castigos, amenazas, coacci√≥n o chantaje emocional.
[#12](c12#c-12) hay ni√±os y ni√±os, los hay que atienden a razonamientos y losnhay que pasan de tu culo ol√≠mpicamente en determinados momentos del d√≠a. No es tan f√°cil.
[#14](c14#c-14) Nadie dijo que fuera f√°cil, al contrario, es mucho m√°s dif√≠cil. Hay momentos en los que es jodidamente dif√≠cil, hay momentos en los que los estrangular√≠as, y hasta hay momentos en los que pierdes los papeles*, como cualquier persona normal. Pero eso no significa que no se merezcan el mismo respeto que cualquier adulto. Lo que muchas veces nos olvidamos es de que su cerebro funciona distinto al nuestro, y que adem√°s no saben c√≥mo funciona el mundo, y es nuestra responsabilidad protegerlos, ense√±arlos y guiarlos.
(*: Y las veces que me ha pasado con mi hijo le pido perd√≥n, como har√≠a con cualquier otro.)
[#16](c16#c-16) totalmente de acuerdo, pero bueno, es que me toca bastante la moral que se venda que todo es posible hablando y explicando las cosas y no, eso no funciona con todos los ni√±os en todo momento.
[#14](c14#c-14) tengo un sobrino con diagn√≥stico tdah, creeme que s√© que no es f√°cil. Pero te aseguro que no sirve absolutamente de nada ejercer violencia, amenazar o castigar.
[#18](c18#c-18) bueno ah√≠ ya hablamos de ni√±os que nunca van a ver el mundo igual que nosotros con lo que interactuar con ellos va a ser siempre de forma diferente.
[#6](c6#c-6) Est√°s confundiendo un grito para evitar una situaci√≥n de peligro, cosa que se har√≠a con cualquiera, ni√±o, adulto o perro, con gritarle a alguien para imponer miedo y autoridad. ¬øO te parece igual de bien que te grite alguien por la calle para evitar que te atropellen que que te grite el subnormal de tu jefe?
Los que est√°n a favor del castigo f√≠sico en ni√±os les propongo hacer lo mismo con adultos. Que te pillan infringiendo una norma vial con el coche, una buena bofetada. Que has hecho mal la declaraci√≥n de la renta, hostia al canto.
Hay muchas maneras de educar, aplicar castigos f√≠sicos es la peor de todas y el √∫ltimo recurso de los incompetentes.
[#3](c3#c-3) El castigo f√≠sico siempre va acompa√±ado de insultos verbales, gestuales adem√°s de amenazas verbales y f√≠sicas.

author: Ron Kampeas
title: Herb Kohl, former Jewish senator from Wisconsin and Milwaukee Bucks owner, dies at 88 - Jewish Telegraphic Agency
text:
( JTA ) ‚Äî Herb Kohl, the longtime Jewish senator from Wisconsin who loved his Milwaukee hometown so much he bought its basketball team to keep it there, has died at 88.
Kohl was known for his soft-spoken, unobtrusive approach as a philanthropist, a retail mogul and a senator, an outlook he said he learned from his Jewish immigrant parents.
Kohl died Wednesday after a short illness, his namesake foundation said.
Elected to the first of four terms in the Senate in 1988, he became an influential member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, where he was a must-meet for pro-Israel lobbyists advocating for defense assistance for Israel. He was a leader on advocacy for children and the elderly, chairing the Senate Aging committee and authoring bills that expanded funding for school lunches and mandated child-safety locks on guns.
‚ÄúThere was always one constituency that everyone in the office knew was more important to Herb than anyone else, and that was children,‚Äù Brad Fitch, a one time spokesman for Kohl, told the Jewish Telegraphic Agency in 2011, after Kohl said his fourth term would be his last . ‚ÄúHe would say, ‚ÄòThey don‚Äôt contribute to campaigns, they don‚Äôt have a lobbyist.‚Äô ‚Äù
He was also a leader in the Jewish community, helming a campaign that raised millions for Israel in a relatively small community in an emergency campaign after the 1967 Six-Day War .
Yet he abjured attention until his middle age, buying the NBA Milwaukee Bucks franchise in 1985, when he was 50, in order to keep them in the city, and then running for the Senate when he was 53.
‚ÄúHe loved sports, he loved Milwaukee and Wisconsin,‚Äù Bud Selig, the Jewish former Major League Baseball commissioner and a childhood friend of Kohl‚Äôs, told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel . ‚ÄúI think his career is so really unusual in this day and age.‚Äù
Kohl was born and raised in Milwaukee. His parents, Max and Mary, had immigrated to Milwaukee from Poland and Russia, respectively, in the early 20th century. Max Kohl opened a grocery store before Herb was born; by the time he reached adulthood, Herb Kohl, one of four siblings, had helped build an extensive chain of grocery and department stores. Kohl left the management in 1979 of a company that now has over 1,000 stores nationwide.
Kohl said his father instilled in his children a strong work ethic ‚Äî Herb Kohl started work in the chain as a bag boy. He said he also learned from his father to keep his emotions in check.
‚ÄúMy father was a person who had a very strong control over his ego and his needs,‚Äù USA Today, in its obituary , quoted Kohl as once saying. ‚ÄúHe was a very driven man, but he was not a person who had the need to belittle people or fight with people or reduce them. He learned to control those impulses, which we all have, I think. He was a very controlled, disciplined person, and he was very influential on me in that respect.‚Äù
In 2016, speaking to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel , Kohl said his father taught him to give back to a community that had welcomed them.
‚ÄúMy father once said, ‚ÄòMoney is like manure. It‚Äôs not good unless you spread it around,‚Äô‚Äù he told the newspaper. ‚ÄúMaybe the day I die all the money will be gone. Whatever. I‚Äôve had a productive life. A happy life. A healthy life. And I never forget it. I‚Äôm very grateful for all the good luck I‚Äôve had in my lifetime.‚Äù
His Jewish expression was low-key but had significant effect. Kohl asked Ray Allen, a star player with the Bucks, to accompany him in 1998 on a tour of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, and it changed the player forever. He was soon urging fellow players to join him on tours whenever they were in Washington to play the Wizards . Allen joined the museum‚Äôs council in 2016 .
Kohl was for a period in the 1990s and 2000s part of an anomalous group of Jewish senators elected from northern midwestern states with small Jewish populations. Russ Feingold served as the junior Wisconsin senator from 1993-2011, and there was a rotation of Jewish senators in neighboring Minnesota in the same period.
Sen. Herb Kohl meets with then Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan, May 12, 2010. (Office of Senator Herb Kohl)
In the Senate, the Democratic politician‚Äôs focus was on oversight and keeping spending within budgets. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm running as a businessman,‚Äù the Journal Sentinel quoted him as saying in its obituary. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a person who hasn‚Äôt spent a nickel until he made a nickel.‚Äù
Kohl self-funded his campaigns so he wouldn‚Äôt be beholden to others, and he did not take kindly to the super-rich.
‚ÄúThe one thing I‚Äôve never appreciated is when I meet people who are successful and some of them think it‚Äôs all about them, that they‚Äôre the ones who made the success and they deserve all the credit,‚Äù he told the Sentinel Journal in his 2016 interview. ‚ÄúBig egos. Dominating personalities. That‚Äôs a bad way to be. I don‚Äôt like people who are overweening in their self-esteem because they‚Äôre wrong and it doesn‚Äôt bode well for people around them. Too often, they‚Äôre also selfish and greedy. It‚Äôs a bad characteristic and I‚Äôve always worked as hard as I can not to be suffused in that kind of thinking.‚Äù
President Joe Biden said his former Senate colleague, one of the richest men in Wisconsin, did not keep easy company with fellow multimillionaires.
‚ÄúThroughout his career, Herb was unafraid to stand up to the business community that he‚Äôd come from, seeking to level the playing field for workers and make our economy more efficient and fair,‚Äù Biden said in a statement Thursday.
His passion was Wisconsin, where he was familiar with the minutiae of its dairy farms, holding up the budget in 1999 for hours until he got through the state‚Äôs farmers‚Äô desired dairy pricing reforms.
The best part of Kohl‚Äôs day was meeting constituents. Each day between 9 a.m. and 10 a.m. was coffee and muffins with Wisconsinites.
‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄúTrying to drag Herb for a hearing away from those breakfasts was impossible,‚Äù Fitch said in 2011.
Kohl bought the Bucks in 1985 when it was rumored that their ailing owner was set to sell the team to buyers who would move the franchise. He dumped millions into the struggling team to keep it in Milwaukee, and when he sold it in 2014, he offered a discount in part to extract a promise that the new owners would keep the team in Wisconsin, and he pledged $100 million to build a new stadium to clinch the deal.
He also gave out $10 million to Bucks employees in bonuses.
‚ÄúEvery day I remind myself how fortunate I‚Äôve been because so much of life is luck,‚Äù Kohl said told the Journal Sentinel in 2016. ‚ÄúI was born into a great family, had a great opportunity at Kohl‚Äôs, and on and on. I‚Äôve had many, many great experiences and very few bad experiences. So what more can you ask for?‚Äù
Kohl, who never married, is survived by his siblings and their children. A nephew, Dan Kohl, helped found J Street , the liberal Jewish Middle East policy group, and ran for Congress unsuccessfully in 2018 .

title: Smart Solutions for Quick Money
text:

author: Redacci√≥n Clar√≠n
title: Choque fatal en C√≥rdoba: ven√≠an discutiendo, ella se tir√≥ del auto y √©l muri√≥ calcinado
text:
Un confuso hecho tuvo lugar este mi√©rcoles por la tarde en Villa Allende, provincia de C√≥rdoba, cuando un Peugeot 307 que circulaba por la avenida Padre Lucchesse choc√≥ de frente con un cami√≥n y se incendi√≥. El conductor qued√≥ atrapado dentro del auto y muri√≥ calcinado. Su acompa√±ante salt√≥ del veh√≠culo y se salv√≥.
Seg√∫n los primeros trascendidos, ambos ven√≠an discutiendo dentro del auto. Por eso, los investigadores consideran una posible maniobra suicida.
Ricardo Osvaldo M√°rquez (46) conduc√≠a este mi√©rcoles a primera hora de la tarde su auto por la avenida Padre Lucchesse, pocos kil√≥metros al noroeste de la capital provincial. Lo acompa√±aba una mujer de 23 a√±os, cuyo nombre no trascendi√≥. Testigos que presenciaron el hecho se√±alaron que ven√≠an discutiendo.
Seg√∫n informaci√≥n de eldocetv, el hombre habr√≠a amenazado con quitarse la vida y, acto seguido, se cruz√≥ al carril contrario, por el que ven√≠a un cami√≥n. Ambos veh√≠culos chocaron de frente y, por la fuerza del impacto, el auto se fue contra un cantero y se incendi√≥. El conductor qued√≥ atrapado dentro del Peugeot.
M√°rquez muri√≥ calcinado. En tanto, su acompa√±ante s√≥lo sufri√≥ heridas leves, al igual que el conductor del cami√≥n, de acuerdo a lo que informaron fuentes policiales
Felipe Crespo, el secretario de Gobierno de Villa Allende, sum√≥ m√°s informaci√≥n sobre el accidente en una conversaci√≥n que tuvo con el medio Cadena 3. Seg√∫n inform√≥, la mujer logr√≥ arrojarse del auto segundos antes del impacto y as√≠ consigui√≥ salvar su vida. El funcionario afirm√≥, adem√°s, que la pareja hab√≠a salido temprano desde la ciudad cordobesa de La Pampa, ubicada en el departamento de Totoral.
üö® AHORA ‚ÄºÔ∏è
‚Äî Polic√≠a de C√≥rdoba (@PoliciaCbaOf)
üìç‚õî CORTE TOTAL - Av. Padre Luchesse y Ruta E-53 - Villa Allende |
üöî Accidente de tr√°nsito entre un autom√≥vil y un cami√≥n. Por causas a establecer el veh√≠culo de menor porte colision√≥ de frente con el cami√≥n, provocando un foco √≠gneo.
üëÆüèºüë®üöíüë©‚öïÔ∏è Trabaja bomberos‚Ä¶[pic.twitter.com/FXoOM2BNgP][April 9, 2025]
El funcionario tambi√©n detall√≥ que la mujer "fue trasladada con lesiones y algunas quemaduras al Hospital de Unquillo, pero est√° bien".
En tanto, la Polic√≠a de C√≥rdoba inform√≥ que hubo un corte total debido al accidente en Av. Padre Luchesse y Ruta E-53, en Villa Allende.

author: Qatar Tribune
title: talabat named ‚ÄòGreat Place to Work‚Äô for 3rd year in a row - Read Qatar Tribune on the go for unrivalled news coverage
text:
Tribune News Network
Doha
talabat, the region‚Äôs leading platform for everyday deliveries, has announced receiving ‚ÄòGreat Place to Work‚Äô certification in Qatar for the third consecutive year.
talabat‚Äôs ethos is grounded in the principles of ‚ÄòMake it Happen, Together We Grow and Experience First‚Äô, with a strong focus on instilling a sense of belonging that enhances openness and fosters empathy among all employees.
Through the establishment of a culture centered around psychological safety, talabat ensures its employees feel valued, supported and empowered to authentically express themselves in the workplace.
Expressing his thoughts on this accomplishment, Francisco Miguel De Sousa, managing director of talabat Qatar, said: ‚Äú It is an amazing accomplishment for talabat to receive this award once again as a clear testament to our dedication of cultivating a great work environment. We are honoured to be receiving this appreciation for the third year and we extend our gratitude to our employees, who are the driving force behind this continuous success.
‚ÄúAt talabat, we remain committed to providing our team with the resources and support necessary for their personal and professional growth, enabling them to realise their full potential.‚Äù
The Great Place to Work Certification is an impartial evaluation of a company‚Äôs workplace culture, employing a rigorous methodology that includes anonymous employee feedback and a thorough analysis of company policies and practices.
The certification stands as a testament to talabat‚Äôs dedication to building a positive environment and workplace culture.
 Copy 28/12/2023 10

author: times news cr
title: Oil prices rise and continue to record gains ¬ª
text:
Follow ‚Äì aware
Oil prices rose for the second session in a row, today, Thursday, as they received support from the possibility of OPEC+ producers taking a decision against increasing production in an important meeting held later today.
Brent crude futures rose by 0.8 percent to $64.60 per barrel, by 05:53 GMT, after rising by more than two percent yesterday, Wednesday.
While West Texas Intermediate crude futures also rose by 0.8 percent to $61.74 per barrel.
Three sources in the OPEC+ group, which includes the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies, said that the group is considering extending production cuts until April, instead of increasing production, as the recovery in demand for oil is still fragile due to the Corona virus crisis.
The market expected that OPEC would ease production cuts by about 500,000 barrels per day, starting next April, and that Saudi Arabia, the largest producer in OPEC, would end a voluntary reduction in its production of an additional one million barrels per day.
Source: Reuters
